Welcome

Welcome to CloudCannon! The easiest way to make static and Jekyll websites updatable for clients, teams and content writers.

This Getting Started tutorial will show you how to go from an HTML website on your computer to a live website your team can update.

First, make sure you have:

  • A free CloudCannon account
  • An HTML website/template on your computer (if you don't have one download one of ours)

Add a Website

The first step is to add a new site to CloudCannon by clicking on the Add a New Site button.

And type in a site name

Now it's time to add files to your website. The easiest way is to upload the files is in the browser, but you can also sync them through Cloud Storage. Click Upload your website files.

Select your website files from your computer.

Now those files have uploaded to CloudCannon, it's time to edit them. Click on index.html to update the homepage.

This will bring up your website in the visual editor. We're going to set the updatable errors. Click on the code editor:

Add a class="editable" to the HTML elements you want to be updatabled. For more information on how editables behave on different elements see the editables section

When you go back to the visual editor view there will a yellow box around the sections with the the editable class.

And that's all there is to it! If you click inside the yellow box you can make updates directly on the page.

File Upload

Uploading files in the browser is the fastest way to get a website going on CloudCannon. Just click on the upload button in the file browser

Then choose if you want to select individual files or upload a whole folder

Once you've selected a file it will be upload to CloudCannon. If you have a cloud storage provider connected, CloudCannon will push the file there too.

Cloud Storage

Connecting a cloud storage provider to CloudCannon allows you to work on your website on your computer. All changes automatically sync to CloudCannon.

Changes made on CloudCannon get synced back to your storage provider.

Dropbox

Go to Storage Providers in your website configuration and click Connect next to Dropbox.

This will bring up a dialog asking for the main source for the initial synchronization. This only matters if you have existing files in CloudCannon or Dropbox, select the source of files you want to keep. Click Connect Dropbox.

This will take you to Dropbox, type in your credentials to continue.

Next you need to click allow to give CloudCannon access to a folder in your Dropbox.

Your Dropbox is now connected to CloudCannon.

Put files in the folder Dropbox->Apps->Cloud Cannon->Your Site Name and they will be synced to CloudCannon. Any changes made on CloudCannon will sync back to your Dropbox.

GitHub

Go to Storage Providers in your website configuration and click Connect next to GitHub.

This will redirect you to GitHub, login and authorize CloudCannon access to your GitHub Account.

You'll be redirected back to CloudCannon to pick a repository to connect. If you don't have one for this website, create a new one in GitHub and refresh this page.

Select the branch you want CloudCannon to pull and push changes to.

This will bring up a dialog asking what the main source is for the initial synchronization. This only matters if you have existing files in CloudCannon or your repository, select the source of files you want to keep. Click Connect GitHub.

GitHub is now connected. Changes you push to the Git Repository are pulled in by CloudCannon. Any changes made on CloudCannon are automatically committed and pushed.

FTP

FTP is another way of syncing files to CloudCannon. You can host your website on any hosting provider with FTP support and use CloudCannon for easy editing. CloudCannon initally pulls in your website then any changes made on CloudCannon are pushed back.

Note: CloudCannon does not continuously sync with FTP after the inital pull. You should make all future updates on CloudCannon to ensure both sides stay in sync.

Connecting FTP

Go to Storage Providers in your website configuration and click Connect next to FTP.

Fill out the FTP details using the details given by your hosting provider. The initial path is usually /public_html or /htdocs.

This will bring up a dialog asking what the main source is for the initial synchronization. This only matters if you have existing files in CloudCannon or FTP, select the source of files you want to keep. Click Connect FTP.

Now any updates you make in CloudCannon are pushed to your hosting provider using FTP.

Visual Editor

The Visual Editor is the main way to edit content in CloudCannon. Areas you can update (or editable regions as we call them) have yellow boxes around them. To an update, click inside a yellow box and update the content inline.

You can navigate to other pages by simply clicking links on the site.

Code Editor

The Code Editor is only availale only to the site creator and users who have had the site shared as a "developer". It's a basic code editor with syntax highlighting, line numbers etc.

Editable Regions

Using editable regions you can control exactly what your users can and can't update using the visual editor.

Adding an editable region is simple, just add class="editable" to an HTML element. If the element already has a class, you can have multiple classes like this: <div class="content editable">. When you switch to the Visual Editor, you'll see a yellow box around that element indicating it's updatable.

There's lots of ways you can use editable regions. To allow everything to be updatable, you could put an editable region on the main content <div> in your HTML. To allow only specific parts to be updatable, you could put the editable region on specific images, paragraphs, lists etc. you want them to update.

Editable regions behave differently depending on what element you put them on. We current support:

img

Gives options to update the images using an image on the site, an uploaded image or an image on the web.

If you've specified a width and height on an image, CloudCannon ensures the new image is the exact same size by cropping the image. The user can drag and move the image to specify how it is cropped.

Text Elements: p, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6

Gives options for bold, italics and links

Inline Elements: span, strong, em

Only allows updating text

Block Elements: div, section, article, aside, footer, header, nav

On block elements you can set headings, bold, italics, links, quotes, lists and images.

Repeatable Regions

Repeatable Regions are useful anywhere you have repeating content. For example, staff profiles or a simple news feed. Users can add, move and delete a the content inside a repeatable region

To use Repeatable Regions, add class="repeatables" to an element in your HTML. The element's direct children then become repeatable regions. Note: All the direct children must all be the same type of element (i.e. div, p, li). To make the content inside the repeatable region updatable you can use editable regions.

Let's go through a quick example for a news section. First, add the HTML for a single news item and then wrap it in a div with a class of repeatables: 

<div class="repeatables">
  <div class="editable">
    <h2>10/01/13 - Exciting News Item!</h2>
    <p>Text for the news item.</p>
  </div>
</div>

Save this and switch to the Visual Editor. The news item now has a yellow icon at top left.

Click on the icon to clone the news item. The HTML will now look like this: 

<div class="repeatables">
  <div class="editable">
    <h2>10/01/13 - Exciting News Item!</h2>
    <p>Text for the news item.</p>
  </div>
  <div class="editable">
    <h2>10/01/13 - Exciting News Item!</h2>
    <p>Text for the news item.</p>
  </div>
</div>

Editable regions work with repeatable regions so can update content inline. Hovering over the news items now displays arrow icons for reordering and a trash can to delete a news item.

Repeatable regions work great in simple cases. For more complex situations, see our Jekyll section.

Javascript

Custom Domains

First off you need to buy your domain name. We recommend using iwantmyname because they have CloudCannon intergration which automatically does the following steps.

Now we need to set up your domain's DNS. What is DNS you ask? The Domain Name System (DNS) translates Internet domain and host names to IP addresses. DNS converts the names we type in our Web browser address bar to the IP addresses of Web servers hosting those sites.

Most domain registrars offer a DNS service. If your provider doesn't then try using namecheap's free DNS service.

To setup:

  • Go into the DNS settings for your domain on your domain registrar's website.
  • Add a new record.

  • Enter the following details:

    Name/Alias - leave blank to configure the root domain (e.g. mysite.com) or enter a value for a subdomain (e.g. enter www to point www.mysite.com at CloudCannon).

    Type - Set to A.

    Value - Set to 184.169.135.34.

One last thing to note: Sometimes you'll want to redirect subdomains to the main domain. For example, let's say you have www.mysite.com and you want visitors who go to mysite.com to redirect to www.mysite.com. Setting this up on CloudCannon is easy, just create DNS records for each domain you want to redirect to your main domain and CloudCannon will handle the redirects.

Custom 404 Page

Add a page called 404.html to the root your website. CloudCannon will serve this page when it can't find a file on your website.

Highlighting Active Links

CloudCannon automatically adds a class of cc-active to any <a> tags which point to the current page. Using CSS and you can style the cc-active class to highlight it.

Pretty URLs

Getting rid of those ugly .html extensions is easy on CloudCannon.

Let’s say you have an about.html page. Create a folder called about, put the about.html file in the about folder then rename about.html to index.html. Now you can link to /about.

Includes

Having the same header/footer across multiple pages can be a hassle when you want to make an update to your template. That's why CloudCannon has an include feature. On any HTML page you can use the following syntax to include any text based file <!-- include another_file.html -->.

Here's an example of how you would have a static header / footer across multiple pages:

First create four files - header.html, footer.html, index.html and about.html.

In header.html put the following: 

<html>
	<head></head>
	<body>
		<div id="navigation">
			<a href="index.html"> Home </a>
			<a href="about.html"> About </a>
		</div>

		<div id="content">

And in footer.html put the following:

		</div>
	</body>
</html>

Now we can include the header and footer into our other HTML pages. Let's start with the index.html page:

<!-- include header.html -->
<h1> My Home page </h1>
<!-- include footer.html -->

and the about page:

<!-- include header.html -->
<h1> About Page </h1>
<!-- include footer.html -->

Now when you makes changes to header.html, it will update on the index and about pages.

301 Redirects

When you change the structure of your website you might want the old URLs to redirect to new pages for SEO reasons. To set up 301 redirect on CloudCannon, first create a file called 301.txt in the root of your website. In this file you can specify the redirects using this syntax: 

 old_url new_url
You can have wildcards by using * and external domains will work too. Here's an example file: 

 /old_file.html /new_file.html
 /category/* /new_category
 /page http://google.com

Form Submissions

We've made it super easy to have contact forms on your website.

Create a normal form element. Make the method post and the action point to the page you want the user to be redirected to after the form submission.

Add the input elements for your contact form. Finally, add a hidden field with a name of cc_emails[] and a value of the email address to send the form submission to.

That's it! Here's an example form: 

<form method="post" action="/success.html">
  <label>First Name</label><input type="text" name="first_name" />
  <label>Surname</label><input type="text" name="surname" />
  <label>Message</label><textarea name="message"></textarea>
  <input type="hidden" name="cc_emails[]" value="mike@cloudcannon.com" />
  <input type="hidden" name="cc_emails[]" value="george@cloudcannon.com" />

  <input type="submit" value="Send Message" />
</form>

Hiding Files From Content Writers

Any file starting with an underscore (e.g. _header.html) are hidden to users with a content writer share to the site.

Share with Content Writers

The Content Writer share level is for sharing a site with users who are non-technical. They do not see the Code Editor or File Browser interfaces. When they edit a site it takes them straight to the Visual Editor.

To share with a site to Content Writer:

  • Go to the Sharing tab in Site Settings
  • Type in the user's email address
  • Click "Share with Developer"

Then update the share level to "View and Update Contents" and press save.

Share with Developers

The Developer share level is for sharing a site with users who need access to the source files. They can do everything the site owner can do except they only site settings they have access to is sharing.

To share with a site to Content Writer:

  • Go to the Sharing tab in Site Settings
  • Type in the user's email address
  • Click "Share with Developer"

Password Sharing

You can also share you site to people without them having to create a CloudCannon account.

Go to the password sharing tab in site settings and enter a password

You can email your clients the website url with /update on the end (e.g. mysite.com/update) and the password. They can log in and do everything a Content Writer can.

Intro

What is Jekyll?

Jekyll is a static site generator. What that means is it takes your content written in HTML, Markdown and other markup languages, passes it through templates and outputs a completley static website

The advantages of doing this are:

  • It's simple - Jekyll is a small step up from HTML so there's not huge amount to learn.
  • Secure - You don't need to worry about the latest PHP vunribility or if your site has an security hole. Your site is just static files which makes it much harder to find security holes.
  • Fast - There's no backend processing or database to access to generate your site, so Jekyll websites are extremly fast.
  • It's powerful - Jekyll opens up a world of new possibilites on static websites. You can blog, have templates, it's hard to belive these are just static websites.

To get started on Jekyll, checkout the offical website

What does CloudCannon's Jekyll integration do?

One of the downsides of using Jekyll is there's no easy way for a non-technical users to update content themselves.

On CloudCannon you can add all the normal CloudCannon editing features to a Jekyll website. CloudCannon also allows non-technical users to blog, manage collections, front matter and data.

Coming Soon

We've tried to make the Jekyll integration "just work" as much as possible. We're working on to make it even easier.

Templates / Includes

At the moment you can't have editable/repeatable regions inside a template or include. It must be in the main content. If you need to add updatable content to a template or include, try using a collection. We're working to make this possible in the future.

Compiling

Each time you make an edit, CloudCannon has to recompile the website before we can show it in the Visual Editor. It usually takes a few seconds. We'll be making this even faster in the future.

Blogging

To blog on your check site you first need to create a _posts folder in the root of your Jekyll website.

Go to the collections tab for your website, you should see two items: Draft Posts and Published Posts. Draft posts are hidden when your site is published.

Let's add a new Draft post, click add draft post button and enter a title for the post

Now click on the file you've just created. It'll open our stripped-back markdown editor. Enter the content for your blog post here.

If you ever want to see the raw markdown (and you're not a Content Writer), go to the Code Editor

You can always configure the layout, blog title and any other Front Matter you've defined by going to the settings tab.

Collections

Collections are like Blogging. Each Collection you define in your _config.yml will be in the collection tab in CloudCannon

If it's a Markdown file you can editing it with our Markdown editor

If it's an HTML file and your have output set to your in your _config.yml you can use the Visual Editor with Editable Regions. If you don't have output set to true you can only use the Code Editor

Front Matter

Front Matter is updated in the settings tab when you have a file open.

It even handles arrays

Website Optimizations

We perform optimizations on CloudCannon websites to make the websites load as fast as possible. All local website assets referenced in the HTML and CSS are served by our CDN. We also minify the CSS files using clean-css and the Javascript using Uglifier.

SSL Support

What's SSL?

SSL is a way of ensuring all the data passed between a website visitor and the server remains private. For websites with login passwords and private data, SSL is essential. For static websites it’s not so important as the website is already public. However, for visitors there’s an extra level of trust from seeing the padlock in their browser.

What’s CloudFlare?

CloudFlare is service which works as a reverse proxy for your website. What that means is when someone visits your website, the request will go to CloudFlare, then CloudFlare will download the website from the hosting provider and serve it to the user.

The advantage of doing this is CloudFlare does many performance and security enhancements so your website will load faster and be more immune to malicious attacks. They’ve also recently added free SSL support.

Why should I care?

Google recently announced that it will prioritise sites that use SSL. Web designers should be approaching clients about SSL to ensure that their clients sites continue to rank well. Given that CloudFlare offers SSL for free AND you get the malicious traffic buffer of their CDN, using it is almost a no-brainer.

Let’s add SSL!

First off, head over to CloudFlare and register a new account

Next it'll ask for your website address

After this CloudFlare will take about a minute to scan your existing DNS records. Once it’s finished it, it’ll show you the DNS records it’s found. You need to verify these records are correct. For CloudCannon websites the DNS records should be fairly simple, usually the setup is:

  • an A record for the root domain pointing to 184.169.135.34
  • an A record for *.rootdomain pointing to 184.169.135.34
  • perhaps an MX record if you have email set up for that domain

Once you’re happy these are correct click the continue button.

Next up is configuring CloudFlare. I switched the plan to free and the performance to CDN + Full optimizations.

Now you need to update your nameservers. To do this log in to your domain provider and change the nameservers to the ones that CloudFlare gives you.

Almost finished! Now go into your CloudFlare Settings

Find the SSL section and change it to "Flexible SSL"

That’s it! Changing your DNS can take up to 48 hours to propagate and CloudFlare’s free SSL can take up to 24 hours to set up. So while there should be no downtime, it might be a day or two before you have SSL and CloudFlare serving your website.
